ratings.comment: Keith is a kindly old guy who needs to retire because of age. We missed about 5-6 lectures because of his poor health. He is clearly brilliant, but also clearly not what he used to be. His passion and care for the students can't be downplayed though. He ended up giving us the actual final to study off of beforehand to make up for his absences.

Has an amazing mind but seems to put mmore time into his research than into classes he teaches. Lectures seemed to be almost a stream of consciousness on his part, were hardly ever helpful and he often talked in circles and went on many tangents. Handouts and emails were littered with typos. I'm never taking a philosophy course again.

Yes, he's hard to understand... Yes, sometimes he talks in circles... But I consider myself privileged to have taken one of his classes.  He's brilliant, he's kind, he's so willing to help.  He's funny and he knows what he's doing.  Take a class with him while you still have a chance.

Yandell is kind of an acquired taste. He mostly appeals to philosophy major. First, he knows his subjects inside out, up and down. But, it can be difficult to understand what he is saying and what point he is making. However, he has great stories, is a happy man, and is happy to help in any way he can. I would recommend him.

Nice guy, but completely incomprehensible.  He talks in circles, and follows no particular outline/ order in lectures. Often would bring up a topic get side tracked on something we weren't supposed to learn until later, and never got back to main point. You will not learn anything from him. At all. Don't bother to go to lectures, or read texts.
He is very jolly!

He's a very nice guy with a brilliant mind for philosophy.  He spends most of his time arguing controversial views, so class is interesting if you're into philos and paying attention.  BUT, he is often difficult to understand.  Makes up for it by answering questions and doesn't mind repeating himself.  His drawings alone are worth going to class.
Awesome guy. Very funny. But he is hard to understand, and he doesn't use the books whatsoever, so don't buy them.

He's such a sweet old man, but this class is just horrible. He talks in circles, goes off on tangents, and half the time, I have no idea what he's even saying (hard to understand both literally and in the stuff he teaches). I wouldn't have passed the class without Kelly Robbins as my TA!

A guy who is genuinely interested in what he lectures about and seems to care about his students.  His lecturing style takes some getting used to, but overall isn't too bad if you pay attention.  Don't pay to get the books, though - he doesn't use them at ALL!

Hate to gripe about lovable people but sadly the Prof is *difficult* to understand.  Wish I had taken the advice of previous posters.  Teaching style is uniquely directed at people who are able to comprehend his method of understanding.

Took him during the summer and it was the most boring 3 hrs of my life. He gives out handouts so there is no point in reading the text or listening to him ramble in lecture. He just sits there & talks w/out direction so his lectures don't flow and he's often repetitious and confusing. Sweet guy though, just HORRIBLE professor. AVOID.
Don't take this class--it's disappointing.  I came in very interested in the subject and left strongly disliking it.  He also did not show up to class 4 times this semester with no heads up.
nice guy...wants you to learn and ask questions.  entertaining at times.  exams are not that bad--essay questions given out a week in advance.  you don't have to do the reading to do well on exams.

What he lacks in clarity  he makes up for in spirit.  He wants you to do well in his class and ask questions.  When you give an incorrect answer in lecture he doesn't belittle you like a lot of phil profs do.
I missed class at least once a week. Read the material before the exam and did fine.  He gives out the questions a head of time.

There really is no overstating how awful Yandell is. He's notorious among philosophy majors as someone to avoid, and is one of the strongest arguments you can find against tenure. His lectures are, truly, incoherent and nonsensical, and a complete waste of time. Whether you enjoy philosophy or not, do yourself a favor, avoid Yandell at all costs.
Santa Claus.  Crazy but fun and world renowned.
I had never fallen asleep in a class at UW untill this summer class.  he was forgiving with his grades, but i have never been so tortured in a lecture.

Attendance is not mandatory, it may help but is not required. He gives out the exam questions one week ahead of time and they are pretty straight forward. If you just take the time to look up the answers in the readings you will do just fine.
Very knowledgeable professor, but can often be hard to follow in lecture. Answers questions well in lecture. Exams are fairly straight forward but difficult. He expects a lot from his students.
Incompetence, thy name is Yandell.

This class was so much harder than it could of been because Yandell could not present his material clearly.  I learned nothing from lecture, but my TA was awesome so it wasn't a complete waste of time.  Wait to take this class with another professor.
Horribly boring, impossible to follow his lectures.  He doesn't use any notes, but just drones on and on.  The class is easy if you have a good TA, but painfully boring anyway.

The class was like dental-work. The TA was far superior and less biased than the professor. As has been said before, a good heart, but a terrible teacher. If you want to take modern, wait to take it with someone else. He tends to muddle more than clarify, making even what's easy about the subject unnecessarily hard.

Horrible professor.  Pathetic teaching style, incompetent lecturer, disorganized, handouts were full of typos and errors.  A full 5 weeks after class ended, he still hasn't recorded my grade after failing to record it correctly the first time.  Avoid this professor at all costs.

Smart guy, knows a lot about what he's teaching.  His lectures can get really boring, and if someone asks a question that he's interested in, he'll take all class answering it.  I honestly went to lecture three times and got a B. The tests are not hard if you study for them, and he usually gives hand-outs for one or two of the questions.

Not especially organized in his lectures, but he covers everything pretty well that will be on the exams. He also hands out review sheets with the questions that will be on the exam about a week before it. The books are written by him and arent really needed if you take good notes in lecture because he pretty much says the same thing.

VERY disappointed with Yandell's course and style.  Extremely unclear about his goals for the course.  I despise each time I have to go to his lectures.  He provides no lecture outlines.  His examples are typically vague and misleading.  I strongly recommend NOT taking any Yandell course.

I'd say as a lecturer he's rather tough to follow, but his exams are straight forward and simple. He also is very willing to spend as much time as nessisary in office hours to make sure you understand the subject.
His lectures are almost unattendable because of his inability to make a clear statement.  Unfortunately, the required books are his as well and have the same problem.

Not a great lecturer.  Sometimes he seems a little disorganized and goes off on tangents.  Despite this he is a brilliant man.  Highly recommended for the philosophically  minded, not a good choice for those without a philosophy background.
Yandell is a fabulous professor if you pay attention.

I was very disappointed by this class. He has a narrow take on the philosophy of religion, and many of the arguments he uses can be seen as value-based or just plain weak. A nice guy, and certainly intelligent, but I expected more.

Professor Yandell is a fascinating lecturer. The topics covered in class and the readings assigned are all very interesting. I would highly recommend this class to anyone with an interest in the subject.
No Comments

He is a philosopher at heart and he is good at it, but the lecture format and lack of discussion opportunities is not a good way to learn philosophy with him.  The class requires you to think on your own and understand arguments on your own terms

Arrogant and irritating. Would provide (poor) evidence for the things he believed and then just say the other theories were wrong with no evidence to back it up that claim. Unclear and bad at answering questions.
He's a great guy and always willing to answer questions.  Unfortunately he was always late to class and would give students money to put in his parking meter half-way through lecture.
This instructor is a poor lecturer.  He is not clear and his class wouldn't be as difficult if he was clear.  In spite of his lack of teaching skills he is a nice guy.
